list.name: Changes
list.comment: Added ABC/123 labels like chess; ready to train overnight for demo

task.summary: Default task

modified the Board's string method to not add a new line at the end as would be expected with most classes; as a result, adding a new line after printing a board is recommended. also modified the text based game to still look the same
Added the TransformableBoard with rotations and reflections.
Implemented == and != for Boards and TransformableBoards; for Boards == is exact equality, and for TransformableBoards, == is equal up to symmetry.
Began work on Version 1.

Re-designed Version 1, including an implementation of matrices (Matrix.py) and transformations (Transformation.py). Also included graphics.py to test Transformation.py, but it will probably be needed later
Extracted Matrix class, toRadians function, and MethodUndefinedError to util.py so they're in one central place instead of scattered across the module wherever they were first needed.
Fixed formatting in all files; added the ability to get the inverse transformation for any Transformation and added transformation functionality to Boards. Next step is MENACE.
Testing to see if I'm logged in on the right account
Testing to see if I'm logged in on the right account
Testing to see if I'm logged in on the right account
Testing to see if I'm logged in on the right account
Minor updates; updated Game.py to only open to and print to gameLogs.txt after each game ends, tested the prototype's performance, and added a TODO to improve Version 1's performance to match.

Changed Transformations to keep track of their inverses with each multiplication, added a Binary Search Tree to util.py for MENACE to use internally, and added code to time how long it takes to play games. Performance has been improved pretty dramatically, but not quite to the level of the prototype; performance warrants further investigation.
test commit from mac

Spent time trying to determine why Version 1's performance is worse; modified Matchbox._generateLegalMoves, however performance is not significantly better. More time should be invested determining which methods take up all the extra time, or else modifying the prototype to be a separate trainer application.

Significantly improved performance issues and fixed bugs. Performance: MENACE now uses a dictionary to store matchboxes, which significantly improved lookup times. Applying transformations to boards seems to be the current bottleneck for performance, so optimizations should be focused there if desired, however current performance seems acceptable: 500 games can be played between two MENACES on my Macbook in under 20 seconds. Bugs: A bug was found in the BinarySearchTree which caused existing matchboxes to not be found when requested; this led to many matchboxes for the same board state. The primary issue was fixed, but some duplicate board states were still found by duplicateChecker.py; no duplicate states have been found since switching away from the Binary Search Tree, so it is likely the culprit.
Improved Transformation.transformedPoint, which brought the performance the rest of the way to more or less matching the Prototype's.
Minimum viable product pretty much achieved; all that's left is polish, including the ability to choose humans/MENACEs from the window, clearer communication when a move is illegal, etc.
Made Prototype its own branch and moved the files out of the Prototype folder. Version 1 is in branch Version-1.
Modified GUI to be clearer, added an end-game GUI so you can see how it ended, and added a training mode that plays games until the user presses ESC.
Modified GUI to be clearer, added an end-game GUI so you can see how it ended, and added a training mode that plays games until the user presses ESC.
Removed additional testing MENACE files.

Performance has been improved pretty dramatically, but not quite to the level of the prototype; performance warrants further investigation.
Test commit from new Mac
test commit from mac

Spent time trying to determine why Version 1's performance is worse; modified Matchbox._generateLegalMoves, however performance is not significantly better. More time should be invested determining which methods take up all the extra time, or else modifying the prototype to be a separate trainer application.

Significantly improved performance issues and fixed bugs. Performance: MENACE now uses a dictionary to store matchboxes, which significantly improved lookup times. Applying transformations to boards seems to be the current bottleneck for performance, so optimizations should be focused there if desired, however current performance seems acceptable: 500 games can be played between two MENACES on my Macbook in under 20 seconds. Bugs: A bug was found in the BinarySearchTree which caused existing matchboxes to not be found when requested; this led to many matchboxes for the same board state. The primary issue was fixed, but some duplicate board states were still found by duplicateChecker.py; no duplicate states have been found since switching away from the Binary Search Tree, so it is likely the culprit.
Improved Transformation.transformedPoint, which brought the performance the rest of the way to more or less matching the Prototype's.
Minimum viable product pretty much achieved; all that's left is polish, including the ability to choose humans/MENACEs from the window, clearer communication when a move is illegal, etc.
Made Prototype its own branch and moved the files out of the Prototype folder. Version 1 is in branch Version-1.
Modified GUI to be clearer, added an end-game GUI so you can see how it ended, and added a training mode that plays games until the user presses ESC.
Removed additional testing MENACE files.
